questionTitle: I want to feel more comfortable around people
questionText:
My son was diagnosed with autism a few years ago and I stopped working so that I could take care of him. I also was dealing with an abusive relationship (mentally, physically, and emotionally). Now I live like a recluse and I always feel nervous around people.
   How can I feel more comfortable around other people?
answerText: There's a lot of layers there to your situation, and I'm focusing on two layers that may be contributing to your feelings of discomfort around others.  One layer is the daunting news that your son has autism.  Many parents can feel overwhelmed and distraught with this diagnosis.  The vast array of treatments available is daunting in and of itself at times to wrap one's head around.  Taking time to reflect or seek out therapy regarding how this diagnosis has impacted you may be helpful.  Some parents feel their individual identity gets lost in the diagnosis because they have dropped everything to help their child, and others may experience guilt.  If either of these or other feelings come to the forefront for you, it may be worth working through them with a therapist.  A support group list is available through www.autismspeaks.org and may help connect you with others raising children with autism.A second layer is the abusive relationship you were involved in.  The trauma you experienced in this relationship may have a very meaningful impact on your ability to trust and to be intimate with others.  Engaging with a therapist can help facilitate the healing process, as well as paving the way for more comfortable and trusting relationships.
response:
It's great that you are taking steps to prioritize your own well-being by stopping work to care for your son and leaving an abusive relationship. However, it's understandable that living with autism and experiencing trauma can make social interactions challenging. Here are some suggestions that may help you feel more comfortable around other people:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by getting enough rest, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy. This will help you feel more grounded and better equipped to handle social situations.
2. Join a support group: Connecting with others who have gone through similar experiences can be incredibly helpful. You can share tips, resources, and emotional support with each other.
3. Take small steps: Start by engaging in low-stakes interactions, such as chatting with a cashier or saying hello to a neighbor. Gradually work your way up to more challenging situations, like attending a social event or participating in a group activity.
4. Use visual aids: If you have autism, you may find it helpful to use visual aids like pictures or diagrams to communicate and understand better. You can also use visual schedules or checklists to help you stay organized and on track.
5. Seek professional help: Consider consulting with a therapist who specializes in anxiety disorders or autism spectrum disorder. They can provide you with additional coping strategies and support.
Remember, it's okay to take things at your own pace and prioritize your own needs. With time and practice, you can learn to feel more comfortable around other people.

questionTitle: How do I cope with separation anxiety while boyfriend is out of town?
questionText:
I have been with my boyfriend for more than a year. He recently got a new job and travels a lot. I’m not used to him being gone all the time. I feel as though he has forgotten about me because he does not talk with me as much and doesn’t keep me up to date on everything that he does throughout the day, which he used to.
 I feel lost, sad and unwanted. This is really a tough new challenge. I just want to break up with him, but I love him so much. I don’t know why he is acting this way lately. I believe I have separation anxiety. Is there anything that I can do to help me cope with this while he is out of town?
answerText: Relationships at any amount of distance can be so hard! It makes sense that you are encountering more anxiety than usual given that major change in your relationship. And you're right that being separated from our partners can heighten our insecurities and worries about not only our relationship security but about our partner's interest. Have you talked with your boyfriend about this struggle you're feeling? It can be hard to have this kind of conversation without triggering a sense of blame and subsequent defensiveness in our partners, but it really is possible. If you have any concerns about being able to do this, then a session or two with a local counselor or therapist might be really helpful - and it really can be just about finding the way to share what you're feeling.As far as coping with anxiety, there are a lot of options but I highly recommend an app called Self-Help for Anxiety Management. There's so much good information in this app to help you learn to pay attention to what kinds of thoughts are helpful or unhelpful, and there are also lots of activities for calming down and decreasing the intensity of that anxiety. The best part is, it's free!
response:
It sounds like you are experiencing a lot of emotional distress due to your boyfriend's recent changes in his work schedule and lack of communication with you. It's understandable that you would feel sad, lost, and unwanted when someone you care about is not around as much as you would like them to be.
Firstly, it's important to recognize that this is a difficult new challenge for both of you, and it may take some time for him to adjust to his new job and schedule. It's possible that he is simply prioritizing his work right now and may not have the same amount of time or energy to devote to our relationship as he did before.
That being said, there are a few things you can do to help cope with these feelings while he is away:
1. Practice self-care: Take care of yourself by doing things that make you feel good, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with friends and family.
2. Stay connected: Even though your boyfriend is gone, try to stay in touch with him through phone calls, video chats, or messaging apps. This can help you feel more connected to him even when he's not physically present.
3. Focus on other relationships: Spend time with friends and family who can provide emotional support during this challenging time.
4. Seek professional help: If you are experiencing overwhelming sadness, anxiety, or other difficult emotions, consider seeking help from a mental health professional. They can provide you with additional coping strategies and support.
5. Give yourself time to adjust: It may take some time for both of you to adjust to these changes in your relationship. Be patient with each other and give yourselves time to work through these challenges together.
Remember, it's okay to feel upset or frustrated when someone you care about is not around as much as you would like them to be. It's important to communicate openly and honestly with each other about how you are feeling and to find ways to cope with these challenges together.

questionTitle: Can anxiety make me think I heard something about me?
questionText: When I'm around people, I sometimes think someone has made a comment to me or asked me to do something. I will be focusing on something else and then randomly think I hear something about me. I never know if it was actually said.
answerText: It sounds like you are having difficulty knowing if people are saying things to you, or if you only thought someone was talking to you, and this is anxiety producing. response: It is common for individuals to experience paranoia or feelings of being watched when they are under stress or experiencing anxiety. This can manifest in various ways, including hearing comments or whispers about oneself even when there is no one around. It's important to recognize that these thoughts and feelings are not based on reality and can be managed through relaxation techniques, mindfulness practices, and seeking support from loved ones or mental health professionals.

questionTitle: How is it that I fear going to sleep?
questionText: I just about fall asleep then I can't help but sit up and walk around.
answerText: Maybe you are afraid to let go of your problems for a few hours.Although you didn't write this, usually what keeps people awake or prevents them from falling asleep are worries about certain situations in their lives.If this describes you then. maybe talk with yourself to convince you that you are entitled to a good night's sleep.Really we all are and feeling rested from the day and life's tensions will better you to handle whatever the particular matters are.Also, maybe you will be more enthusiastic to go to bed if you have a comfy mattress and nice pillows!  Make your bed an inviting place because this will tempt you to enjoy relaxing enough to go to sleep!
response:

First, it's important to establish a consistent sleep schedule and create a relaxing bedtime routine. This can involve activities such as reading, taking a warm bath, or practicing relaxation techniques like deep breathing or meditation.
Another strategy is to avoid stimulating activities before bedtime, such as watching TV or using electronic devices. These can be stimulating and make it harder to fall asleep. Instead, try to focus on calming activities that promote relaxation.
Additionally, you may want to consider trying some relaxation techniques, such as progressive muscle relaxation or guided imagery, to help calm your mind and body before bedtime. These can be especially helpful if you are experiencing stress or anxiety that is interfering with your ability to fall asleep.
Finally, it may be helpful to talk to a mental health professional about any underlying issues that may be contributing to your difficulty sleeping. They can provide support and guidance on how to manage these issues and improve your overall sleep quality.
Remember, getting enough sleep is important for both physical and mental health. Don't hesitate to seek help if you are struggling with sleep difficulties.

questionTitle: Do I have some type of anxiety?
questionText: Sometimes, I'm fine and can go out or meet people, but other days, my heart races and words physically cannot come out of my mouth. I've always thought it was normal and I was just nervous, but the other day, it took me almost 30 minutes of sitting in my car to find the courage to enter Target by myself.
answerText: It is possible that you could have or be developing an anxiety disorder. There isn't really enough information provided here to suggest a particular disorder, but it might be worth meeting with a counselor or therapist to do a formal assessment. Some of the questions they might ask could be what other kinds of physical symptoms you experience, how frequently these physical symptoms happen, what's going on for you when they tend to happen, and how frequently/intensely you find yourself worrying in general. Anxiety itself is a really natural thing - it's just when it starts interfering with your ability to "do life" the way you want that we start to consider potential disorders. It might be that for the most part, the anxiety you feel is normal and you simply have some triggers that intensify it more than usual. Working on your own or with the support of a counselor/therapist to both address those triggers at the root and also to develop ways of managing the actual anxiety symptoms. This two-fold approach can be really helpful for not letting anxiety keep you from engaging in life the way you'd like.
response:
It sounds like you may be experiencing a common phenomenon known as "social anxiety." This can manifest in different ways, such as feeling nervous or self-conscious in social situations, and having difficulty speaking up or being yourself around others. It's important to remember that you are not alone in experiencing this, and there are many resources available to help you manage your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.
One approach that may be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which can help you identify and challenge negative thought patterns and behaviors associated with social anxiety. You may also find it helpful to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, when you are feeling anxious in social situations.
Additionally, there are many self-help resources available that can provide you with additional support and guidance. These may include books, online courses, or support groups for people with social anxiety. It's important to remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness, and can be an important step towards improving your overall well-being.
Finally, it may be helpful to practice self-compassion and to be kind to yourself when you are feeling anxious or overwhelmed. Remember that it is okay to feel nervous or unsure in social situations, and that these feelings do not define your worth or identity. With time, patience, and support, you can learn to manage your social anxiety and live a more fulfilling and confident life.

questionTitle: What do I do when I have anxiety attacks?
questionText: I get so much anxiety, and I don’t know why. I feel like I can’t do anything by myself because I’m scared of the outcomes.
answerText: This is a very common question in my practice. Panic attacks typically emerge from an underlying issue (ex. Depression, low self-esteem, fears). To decrease your anxiety symptoms it’s recommended to seek treatment with a therapist who specializes in working with anxiety disorders and most importantly one with whom you feel comfortable with.In my practice I educate clients about their anxiety and discuss building a framework with helpful tools for decreasing anxiety:1. Starting a daily mindfulness practice. For example: listening to guided meditation; engaging in deep breathing exercises; yoga practice; or other positive calming activities.2. Understand your negative and positive thoughts. Many times we tend to focus on the potential for bad things to happen. Increase positive self-talk when feeling down or when anxious. For example: "I don't need to worry, I am calm and relaxed". 3. Exposure to fearful or anxious situations. This can be accomplished under the care of a mental health professional. Many times we shy away from things that make us feel uncomfortable or insecure. This may led to an increase in isolating behaviors resulting in difficulty in performing things we were once able to do. For example: leaving the house; presenting in front of others; going to social events; and having conversations with people. However, the more we expose ourselves and practice the use of our positive coping skills (ex. deep breathing) the chances of anxiety will decrease. I hope this was helpful. Keep in mind, a therapist can help with guiding you through self relaxation and improvement.
response:
It sounds like you may be experiencing some level of social anxiety or insecurity about yourself and your abilities. This can manifest in feelings of nervousness or panic when interacting with others, or a general sense of unease about your own self-worth. It's important to remember that everyone experiences these feelings at times, and they are not necessarily reflective of your actual abilities or worth as a person.
One way to start addressing these feelings is to practice self-compassion and self-acceptance. This can involve treating yourself with kindness and understanding, rather than beating yourself up over perceived shortcomings. It can also help to challenge negative self-talk and replace it with more positive affirmations.
Another strategy is to focus on building your self-esteem and confidence through small, achievable goals. By setting and achieving these goals, you can gradually build your sense of self-worth and competence. This can help to reduce feelings of anxiety and insecurity over time.
Finally, consider seeking support from friends, family, or a mental health professional. Talking through your feelings with someone who cares about you can be a powerful way to gain perspective and develop coping strategies for managing anxiety.
Remember, it's okay to feel anxious at times, and it's important to be kind to yourself as you work through these feelings. With time and effort, you can learn to manage your anxiety and cultivate a more positive sense of self-worth.

questionTitle: Sleeping, Anger and Anxiety
questionText: I have a lot of issues going on right now. First of all, I have a lot of trouble sleeping at times, while other nights I sleep too much and still feel quite tired. I’m also noticing increased irritability and experiencing anxiety attacks that last for hours. Is there something wrong with me and if so what should I do?
answerText: Hi there. I have to commend you on reaching out to get some answers on why you are feeling the way that you are feeling. A lot of people secretly go about their lives every day feeling this way because they are too afraid of what the answer might be.First off, what stressors do you have in your life right now? Financial, relationship and unemployment are all common stressors for people. They can often make it difficult for us to sleep at night due to the constant racing thoughts and wonders of how you will deal with it all. Secondly, do you have a history of depression or does depression run in your family? Some of the symptoms listed here in this question (i.e. trouble sleeping, constant fatigue, too much sleep, anger & anxiety) are all common symptoms of depression. Often times, these symptoms can be overlooked and mistaken for "just being tired." Furthermore, it's important to ask yourself, if you are feeling worthless, problems with concentration and recurrent thoughts of death. If you are having these symptoms, please seek help IMMEDIATELY. Lastly, considering your stated symptoms I would recommend reaching out to your Doctor for further consult. It's always better to be safe and the earlier you catch the symptoms the faster you will get to feeling better! do Some helpful tips for the your Doctor would be to monitor your sleep habits (i.e. how much or little are you sleeping), make a list of your triggers for your anger outbursts as well as your triggers for your anxiety attacks. I hope this was helpful and the best of luck to you.
response:
It sounds like you are dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety, which can definitely impact your sleep and overall mood. While it’s normal to have some difficulty sleeping from time to time, the frequency and intensity of your symptoms suggest that there may be an underlying issue worth exploring further.
Firstly, I would recommend seeking professional help from a therapist or counselor who specializes in anxiety and mood disorders. They can help you identify any underlying causes of your symptoms and develop coping strategies to manage them more effectively. It’s important to remember that dealing with stress and anxiety is not something you can simply “snap out of” or overcome through willpower alone, so don’t be afraid to reach out for support.
In addition to seeking professional help, there are some things you can try at home to help manage your symptoms:
1. Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation to help calm your mind and body before bedtime.
2. Establish a consistent sleep schedule by going to bed and waking up at the same time every day, including weekends.
3. Create a relaxing bedtime routine that signals your body that it’s time to wind down, such as reading a book, taking a warm bath, or practicing yoga or tai chi.
4. Avoid caffeine and electronics for at least 2-3 hours before bedtime, as they can interfere with your ability to fall asleep and disrupt your sleep patterns.
5. Try keeping a sleep diary to track your symptoms and identify any patterns or triggers that may be contributing to your difficulty sleeping.
Remember, it’s important to take your symptoms seriously and seek professional help if they are impacting your quality of life. With the right support and strategies in place, you can learn to manage your stress and anxiety more effectively and improve your overall well-being.

questionTitle: I have come to the realization that my boyfriend and I want different things

response:
